Dr. Peter H. Rossi, Social Relations, has received a .
$246,139 grant from the
Department of Justice to
conduct a 15 month study
entitled "The Potentials for
Change in State Penal Systems."
Although Rossi has not
received actual notification of
the grant, he has heard "official
rumors" from the Department of
Justice and the Baltimore
Evening Sun.
Rossi will collaborate in the
study with Dr. Richard Berk of
Northwestern University in
Evanston, Illinois. Berk received
his doctorate from Hopkins and
worked with Rossi as a graduate
student.
Communications between
Rossi and Berk will be facilitated
by a computer system located in
Rossi's office.

Rossi said the study will
concentrate on the "politics of
corrections law — and the
methods in which penal reforms
are enacted.
He explained that an integral
part of the study will be the 110
with state officials
in
connected with penal systems,
such as governors, state
legislators, and corrections
officials. The interviews will be
conducted by an auditing and
surveying firm located in New
York City.

Commenting various state
penal systems, Rossi said
"Massachusetts has probably the
most advanced system." Rossi
cited the fact that a large number
of Massachusetts prisoners are
placed in community situations
as a reason for the state's relative
success in penal reform.

At the present time, Rossi is
devising a questionnaire that will
soon be distributed in the
Baltimore area. The
questionnaire will serve as a
measuring device to see which
crimes are considered "serious"
in the public eye.
"Penal reforms are designed to
provide a different method of
rehabilitation for different
crimes," Rossi explained, "but
there are dertain types of crimes
that are so serious in the public
view, that the prisoners are
incarcerated."
Rossi added that the most
important step in penal reform.is
to discontinue the use of "forced
rehabilitation,— which was
carried to an extreme in the
movie A Clockwork Orange.

method provides no actual

By MARK SCAN LAN
The Lyric is an impressive theatre. Its
brass railings and plush boxes recall the
days in the first quarter of this century
when Baltimore was a city of cultural
vitality; when its theatre, opera and
sy mphony matched any on this
continent.
I came 45 minutes early to the Lyric
Wednesday evening and watched it fill to
near capacity with every manner of
Baltimorean. There were the aged urban
aristocracy, who fit in well with the
tattered elegance of the hall, the opulent
suburbanites, who would not be outdone,
and the long-haired young, who, like
everyone else showed a drowsy reluctance
for such entertainments as the symphony,
and a doubt that any orchestra, especially
Baltimore's, could arouse them.
But on the stage strode a man who, for
the past four seasons has fought valiantly
to dispell such doubts. If there is one man
most responsible for the survival of the
symphony through its financial crisis last
winter, it is Sergiu Comissiona, who
attacks cultural apathy with an innovative
approach to programming, as his program
of Wednesday evening proved.
My reason for being there 45 minutes
early was to catch a lecture
demonstration given before the concert
by assistant conductor Murray Sidlin. His
presentation (to an unfortunately small
group) fondly recalled the lectures I used
to attend as a child given by Leonard
Bernstein and The New York
Philharmonic. Mr. Sidlin had all the
facility and humor, if not the charisma,
of Bernstein, as he explained some of the
history and structure .of the music we
were about to hear. I greatly approve of
this experiment, such a preview can add a
great deal to appreciation, can give the
listener something to latch on to,
especially with the unfamiliar sounds of
modern composers.
One point Mr. Sidlin stressed was how.
infrequently the concert's three pieces
have been performed. Conductors shy
away from Bartok's Divertimento for
String Orchestra because of a reluctance
to separate the strings from the remainder
of the orchestra. When it is performed, it
is usually done in the style of a concerto
grosso, with a select ensemble of soloists.

Maestro Comissiona is unafraid of the
unusual. He decided to do it with all his'
strings.
Like all Bartok's music it makes great
technical demands. It calls for such tonal
inventiveness that a group of strings can
sound like at-) entire orchestra; a violin
must be able to sound trumpet-like, a
cello must imitate a bassoon. The
orchestra stood up very well to this
requirement. Handling the rhythmic and
dynamic demands of the work, however,
they were less successful. Bartok drew
heavily on the folk music of Eastern
Europe, a tradition more familiar to
Maestro Comissiona,&Rumanian, than to
his players. He tried a strorig and clipped
attack, puncing the air with his baton,
but the violins were not brave enough to
launch into this unfamiliar territory with
confidence. This was particularly
apparent in the first movement which
also calls for a volumetric range the
ensemble simply could not provide.
The performance improved in the

second movement, which gave the violas
an opportunity to show their competence
with tender lyrical passages. In the
sprightly and humorous third movement,
the violins again lacked rhythmic
precision, often too noticeably lagging
behind the determined attack of
concertmaster Isidor Saslav.
The highlight of the evening was
Benjamin Britten's Diversions on a
Theme. Contemporary with the Bartok
composition, it, too, belies the difficulty
of the period in which it was composed.
Diversions is actually one of an unusual
species of piano concerto performed
entirely by the left hand. Britten wrote it
for the Viennese pianist Paul
.Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in
World War I. Wednesday evening it was
performed by Leon Fleisher who also
performs only with his left hand (the
woman sitting next to me said it was due
to arthritis, but I was not able to verify
this). A pianist restricted to such a small
repertory, must have the opportunity to
develop a deeper understanding for each
work he performs. With Britten's
Diversions, Mr. Fleisher displayed an
emotional understanding as great as his
technical control: one moment rendering
a delicate background of perfect
arpeggioes, at the next, jumping registers
with stunningly forceful chords. It
sounded to me as if he were playing with
both hands, but there always was his right
hand, sometimes lying relaxed on his
thigh, sometimes tightly gripping the side
of the keyboard as if struggling to confine
his expressive energy to the piano.
Mr. Fleisher's sensitivity made him
ever-conscious of his being part of the
orchestra, whose sound had now vastly
improved with the addition of
woodwinds, brass and percussion. The
complement added the dynamic strength
missing in the Bartok. Also contributing
to a better performance was the greater
familiarity of the Britten work, which the
pounding jazz-like rhythms in the
percussion and brass that American
orchestras understand best. After an
ending of impressive crescendoes, Mr.
Fleisher took seven bows to a now
enlivened audience, many of whom stood
and bravoed.
The concert ended with a coup of

programming genius. Maestro Comissiona
had come from the alien strains of Bartok
to the comfortable familiarity of
Tchaikowsky's Second Symphony in C
Minor. First attempted by the Baltimore
Symphony 30 years ago under the
direction of Igor Stravinsky, it, too, is
infrequently performed. Although the
movements within themselves are
completely coherent, full of
Tchaikowsky's genius for melody and
alternating motives, between the
movements there is little thematic
interrelationship, a fact which would
seem less of a drawback to our confused
age than it did one hundred years ago.
Comissiona showed that it can, indeed, be
a very popular piece.
This is the stuff symphony orchestras
were made for. Here is the opportunity
for the conductor to grit his teeth and
shake his fists. The Maestro looks as a
symphony conductor should, with
angular facial features and a bush of
tousled hair attached to a skeleton draped
in tails.
He also moves as a symphony
conductor should: thrusting his baton
through a strong and brassy first
movement, bouncing like a puppet with
his arms at his sides for the second (a
light-hearted march similar to the march
from The Nutcracker), pinching every
delicate note from the scherzo third
movement, and finishing the symphony
with a fine piece of violence, with valiant
baton flourishes high in the air, and full,
twisting swipes to generate the volume
needed for the typical Tchaikowsky
bombastic ending.
And a bombastic ending it was. One
could plainly see the powerful effect
Comissiona had made on his audience,
and the long-range effect he must have

Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, Director

prohibitions that influence all the

response to hypnosis."
According to Shaffer, in

degree of concentration but

sense, is not going on since
reality is screened out." He also
indicated that verbal selection
during hypnosis produces

physiological changes.
Experiments conducted by

hypotheses. In one experiment,
five different groups of people,
students, mental patients,
psychologists and psychiatrists,

By MARK SCAN LAN
The Lyric is an impressive theatre. Its
brass railings and plush boxes recall the
days in the first quarter of this century
when Baltimore was a city of cultural
vitality; when its theatre, opera and
sy mphony matched any on this
continent.
I came 45 minutes early to the Lyric
Wednesday evening and watched it fill to
near capacity with every manner of
Baltimorean. There were the aged urban
aristocracy, who fit in well with the
tattered elegance of the hall, the opulent
suburbanites, who would not be outdone,
and the long-haired young, who, like
everyone else showed a drowsy reluctance
for such entertainments as the symphony,
and a doubt that any orchestra, especially
Baltimore's, could arouse them.
But on the stage strode a man who, for
the past four seasons has fought valiantly
to dispell such doubts. If there is one man
most responsible for the survival of the
symphony through its financial crisis last
winter, it is Sergiu Comissiona, who
attacks cultural apathy with an innovative
approach to programming, as his program
of Wednesday evening proved.
My reason for being there 45 minutes
early was to catch a lecture
demonstration given before the concert
by assistant conductor Murray Sidlin. His
presentation (to an unfortunately small
group) fondly recalled the lectures I used
to attend as a child given by Leonard
Bernstein and The New York
Philharmonic. Mr. Sidlin had all the
facility and humor, if not the charisma,
of Bernstein, as he explained some of the
history and structure .of the music we
were about to hear. I greatly approve of
this experiment, such a preview can add a
great deal to appreciation, can give the
listener something to latch on to,
especially with the unfamiliar sounds of
modern composers.
One point Mr. Sidlin stressed was how.
infrequently the concert's three pieces
have been performed. Conductors shy
away from Bartok's Divertimento for
String Orchestra because of a reluctance
to separate the strings from the remainder
of the orchestra. When it is performed, it
is usually done in the style of a concerto
grosso, with a select ensemble of soloists.

Maestro Comissiona is unafraid of the
unusual. He decided to do it with all his'
strings.
Like all Bartok's music it makes great
technical demands. It calls for such tonal
inventiveness that a group of strings can
sound like at-) entire orchestra; a violin
must be able to sound trumpet-like, a
cello must imitate a bassoon. The
orchestra stood up very well to this
requirement. Handling the rhythmic and
dynamic demands of the work, however,
they were less successful. Bartok drew
heavily on the folk music of Eastern
Europe, a tradition more familiar to
Maestro Comissiona,&Rumanian, than to
his players. He tried a strorig and clipped
attack, puncing the air with his baton,
but the violins were not brave enough to
launch into this unfamiliar territory with
confidence. This was particularly
apparent in the first movement which
also calls for a volumetric range the
ensemble simply could not provide.
The performance improved in the

second movement, which gave the violas
an opportunity to show their competence
with tender lyrical passages. In the
sprightly and humorous third movement,
the violins again lacked rhythmic
precision, often too noticeably lagging
behind the determined attack of
concertmaster Isidor Saslav.
The highlight of the evening was
Benjamin Britten's Diversions on a
Theme. Contemporary with the Bartok
composition, it, too, belies the difficulty
of the period in which it was composed.
Diversions is actually one of an unusual
species of piano concerto performed
entirely by the left hand. Britten wrote it
for the Viennese pianist Paul
.Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in
World War I. Wednesday evening it was
performed by Leon Fleisher who also
performs only with his left hand (the
woman sitting next to me said it was due
to arthritis, but I was not able to verify
this). A pianist restricted to such a small
repertory, must have the opportunity to
develop a deeper understanding for each
work he performs. With Britten's
Diversions, Mr. Fleisher displayed an
emotional understanding as great as his
technical control: one moment rendering
a delicate background of perfect
arpeggioes, at the next, jumping registers
with stunningly forceful chords. It
sounded to me as if he were playing with
both hands, but there always was his right
hand, sometimes lying relaxed on his
thigh, sometimes tightly gripping the side
of the keyboard as if struggling to confine
his expressive energy to the piano.
Mr. Fleisher's sensitivity made him
ever-conscious of his being part of the
orchestra, whose sound had now vastly
improved with the addition of
woodwinds, brass and percussion. The
complement added the dynamic strength
missing in the Bartok. Also contributing
to a better performance was the greater
familiarity of the Britten work, which the
pounding jazz-like rhythms in the
percussion and brass that American
orchestras understand best. After an
ending of impressive crescendoes, Mr.
Fleisher took seven bows to a now
enlivened audience, many of whom stood
and bravoed.
The concert ended with a coup of

programming genius. Maestro Comissiona
had come from the alien strains of Bartok
to the comfortable familiarity of
Tchaikowsky's Second Symphony in C
Minor. First attempted by the Baltimore
Symphony 30 years ago under the
direction of Igor Stravinsky, it, too, is
infrequently performed. Although the
movements within themselves are
completely coherent, full of
Tchaikowsky's genius for melody and
alternating motives, between the
movements there is little thematic
interrelationship, a fact which would
seem less of a drawback to our confused
age than it did one hundred years ago.
Comissiona showed that it can, indeed, be
a very popular piece.
This is the stuff symphony orchestras
were made for. Here is the opportunity
for the conductor to grit his teeth and
shake his fists. The Maestro looks as a
symphony conductor should, with
angular facial features and a bush of
tousled hair attached to a skeleton draped
in tails.
He also moves as a symphony
conductor should: thrusting his baton
through a strong and brassy first
movement, bouncing like a puppet with
his arms at his sides for the second (a
light-hearted march similar to the march
from The Nutcracker), pinching every
delicate note from the scherzo third
movement, and finishing the symphony
with a fine piece of violence, with valiant
baton flourishes high in the air, and full,
twisting swipes to generate the volume
needed for the typical Tchaikowsky
bombastic ending.
And a bombastic ending it was. One
could plainly see the powerful effect
Comissiona had made on his audience,
and the long-range effect he must have
with continued successes. The Maestro
and his orchestra are doing their part to
make Baltimore a place where fine music
can thrive.
